page.title: 08POULTRY AT TEMPLE NORMANTON
page.content: In Temple Normanton is an old family poultry farm owned by the Wright brothers. Farms like it are unusual because the fowls are kept mainly for breeding purposes. Chickens from the farm are supplied to various parts of the country. The eggs are placed in an incubator for 21 days and are turned regularly. Once hatched the chicks are sexed and most of the males destroyed. The pullets are kept in a warm shed for a further two months before being let out into the free range pens. There are no batteries on this farm. There are about 2000 adult birds and 400 chickens at any one time. About 250 eggs are collected each evening and suitable ones used for further breeding. The most common breeds are Rhode Island Reds and Leghorns.
